Mr Ruddock-The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) is responsible, on behalf of the Commonwealth, for matters to do with the repatriation of indigenous cultural property from overseas. As part of its responsibilities ATSIC may fund indigenous community projects directed at reclaiming ancestral remains. ATSIC is not actively engaged in approaching overseas collecting institutions seeking the return of Aboriginal human remains. Reclaiming material from the national institutions of other countries a delicate issue, and Australia has encouraged its overseas postings to use their influence wherever possible to encourage overseas bodies to release human remains. Aircraft Incident (Question No. 162) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998: Was a Qantas passenger jet forced to take evasive action to avoid a turboprop Metroliner freight plane about 10 p.m on 22 July 1998; if so (a) what were the circumstances and (b) will he review operating procedures for pilots crossing runways to ensure that pilots stop before crossing a runway and wait for permission to proceed from the control tower. Mr Anderson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Yes, there was an incident on 22 July 1998 involving a Qantas passenger jet and a turboprop freight plane. (a) According to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI), the circumstances surrounding the incident were as follows: * A Metro aircraft landed on runway 34R, with an instruction to exit on taxiway Tango 1 and taxi via taxiway Juliet (for identitlcation purposes, runways are named in accordance with the international phonetic alphabet). When approaching a mandatory holding point on taxiway Juliet, the pilot contacted the surface movement controller (SMC) and was instructed to taxi via taxiway Bravo and hold short of runway 25. This instruction was read back correctly by the pilot. * Tower controllers subsequently observed the Metro taxiing along taxiway Juliet, past the entry to taxiway Bravo, towards runway 34L. At that time a Boeing 737 (B737) was touching down on runway 34L. The SMC instructed the pilot of the Metro to stop. As there was no reply the instruction was immediately repeated, and was subsequently acknowledged. The Metro came to a stop at the edge of runway 34L. The pilot of the B737 was also instructed to stop immediately, but the aircraft was too close to the intersection of the runway with taxiway Juliet to comply. The B737 was steered to the left of the runway centreline to increase its separation from the Metro, subsequently passing about 25 metres in front of that aircraft, at about 80 kts. * At the time of the occurrence the weather was fine, there were no works taking place in the vicinity of the runway/taxiway intersection, and all relevant taxiway lights, runway holding point lights and movement area guidance signs were reported to have been functioning normally. The investigation is continuing. BASI will send a copy of the final report if requested to do so. (b) According to Airservices Australia, aerodrome procedures were reviewed as a result of this incident. Procedures for pilots requiring to cross a runway are detailed in the Aeronautical Information Publication. The runway crossing point is marked by holding lights and illuminated signs identifying the runway. Communications between air traffic controllers and pilots have been amended to further clarify the need for pilots to obtain a specific clearance to cross a runway. It was flying between 100 feet and 200 feet above sea level and two miles off the coast, when, abeam Coolangatta, it was required to climb to 6000 feet and track West. None. (c) One. (d) Executive Officer No 1 Squadron, RAAF Amberley. (e) The aircraft, one of five Fll1s flying a standard flight route from Evans Head Air Weapons Range to RAAF Amberley, via Brisbane Airport to conduct Instrument Landing System approach training, encountered a higher fuel usage than planned and requested an amended Air Traffic Control (ATC) clearance direct to AmberJey, from fly a position abeam Coolangatta. ATC approval was given, with the proviso that the aircraft be at 6000 feet altitude before crossing the coast. The crew then conducted a rapid climb before returning by the shortest route to Amberley. (f) The flight was conducted strictly in accordance with approved and authorised operational requirements and safety precautions. All RAAF and ATC instructions were adhered to. (g) Two miles.
